title: CTRL0000071092 - Transcribed Interview of Lewis Cantwell, (Apr. 26, 2022)

data.text: JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL,
The interview in the above matter was held via Webex, commencing at 4:02 p.m.
For the SELECT COMMITTEE TO INVESTIGATE
THE JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL:
The Law Office of Nie Cocis
We will go on the record at 4:02 p.m. eastern time.
This a transcribed interview of Mr. Lewis Cantwell -- I know he
goes by "Easton" -- conducted by the House Select Committee to Investigate the
January 6th Attack on the United States Capitol pursuant to House Resolution 503.
At this time, I'd ask the witness to please state your full name and spell your last
This will be a staff-led interview, and members, of course, may also choose to ask
other committee members, staff, or congressional Members in the room today.
At this time, could counsel please state their full name for the record?
And can you spell your last name for us, Mr. Cocis?
We have an official reporter transcribing the record for this interview.
wait, Mr. Cantwell, until each question is completed before you begin your response, and
I'll try to wait until your response is complete before I ask my next question.
The stenographer cannot record nonverbal responses, such as shaking your head,
so it's important that you answer each question with a verbal response.
shaking your head, I'll just annotate it for the record with a positive or a negative
So if you hear me saying that, that's why I'm doing it.
And we ask that you provide complete answers based on your
If the question's not clear, just ask me to restate it, and I can try to
If you don't know the answer to the question, please simply say so.
First, it's important that you understand that this interview is voluntary.
any time you would like to stop speaking with us, that's your choice.
Similarly, if at any point you need to discuss something with your attorney in
private, please let us know, and we'll take a break so you can have that conversation.
Second, this interview is not under oath, but because this is a
formal congressional investigation, you are obligated under Federal law to tell the truth,
the same as if you were speaking with the FBI or DOJ.
could result in criminal penalties for false statements.
So, for this interview, providing false information
So do you understand that as well?
You are not obligated to keep the fact of this interview and what
You are free to tell whoever you want that you met with us,
including the prosecutor or judge in your case, or you can tell no one at all.
But it's important that you know that the select committee is separate and
independent from the DOJ, that we have no involvement with your prosecutions, and the
DOJ is not a partner to the committee in our investigation.
The select committee also is not a party to your criminal case, is not agreeing to
submit anything on your behalf to the judge, nor can we make any representations
whether, if you tell the judge that you met with us, that the judge will be more favorable
Do you understand that as well?
As Mr. Cocis had mentioned before we went on the record, we've
agreed that we will not share the substance of what you say with DOJ prior to your
But there are two possible exceptions that you should be aware of.
So if you tell us about evidence of a crime that we thought that law enforcement
was unaware of or if we had reason to believe that you had lied to us during this
interview, then we will be obligated to tell DOJ or another appropriate law enforcement
Or if you told the judge that you met with us, please understand that that may
prompt questions from the judge about what you said and whether it is consistent with
your prior statements and acceptance of responsibility.
questions, we may get asked to respond and divulge what you said.
So if the judge starts asking
So is that clear as well?
Mr. Cocis, is that what you were talking about before?
Yeah, that's what I was talking about before.
Logistically, please let us know if you need any breaks or would like to discuss
There might be individuals who join later on.
If they do, I'll make sure that I
annotate it for the record and also let you know so that you're aware.
And, again, if you don't understand a question, please just ask me to repeat it,
So, Mr. Cantwell, please tell us a little bit about yourself, like
where you're from, where you live, your educational background.
I'm originally from Fernandina Beach, Florida, born in Jacksonville, Florida.
I live in Canton, North Carolina, a small town outside of Asheville, North Carolina, in the
I graduated high school and went to college at the University of North Florida for
And then I joined the military, and I stayed for another couple of years.
And then I was discharged and worked a variety of jobs my whole life and moved around,
As a fellow veteran, thank you for your service.
What was the characterization of it?
So what do you do for a living now?
I work on fiber-optic networks for internet
So, like, I bring internet to businesses and homes and stuff, help design the
What was your job while you were in the military?
18-series and then ended up getting recycled, and while I was recycled, I ended up going
to EOD school, and that's where I finished, with EOD.
Other than your Army career and the fiber-optic-type work you're doing now,
have you had any other careers?
I've been a chef in, you know, a high-capacity restaurant, fine dining, 500
I've been the general manager of a trucking company that sold semi trucks and
bought trucks all over the country.
I've sold -- not only did I run that company, but I used to sell motor homes and
yachts and boats and stuff like that, too --
So, for these next questions, the timeframe we're thinking about is during former
And a variety of other things.
Well, let's go, I guess, then, to the lead-up to January 6th.
when he was President is what we're really thinking about here.
So, in general, how would you have described your level of political engagement
I've always been very politically active.
I study -- like, I'm one of the few people
who probably know all my politicians, my Congressmen, my Senators in my area.
very good track of everything to do with politics?
I'm actually -- just to note it, I'm not -- I'm pretty much independent.
conservative, but I have a ton of different values that I share on all sides of the political
scheme, so I'm not really biased.
I owned a business that I started in 2018, and under that -- which I didn't mention
before, but I had a business for 3 years, a teahouse, that -- I sold teas that helped
people with, like, drug addiction and pain relief and all kinds of stuff, like headaches,
And it was kind of a hang-out spot.
And it did very well during his tenure as Presidency, I guess you could say, until
And that really put a lot of strain on my business.
know, that whole year of 2020 was just pretty chaotic, with everyone, you know, freaking
out all over the place, like, just --
-- riots and different things here and there.
So I'd never been to a rally before that day or a political anything.
vigil for George Floyd not long after he died, but that wasn't a rally.
a procession with candles with a bunch of people in a local small town where we just --
But I had never been to any, like, political rallies
where there was political people there, you know.
the news, and that's pretty much it.
I followed them on social media and
I was not very, like, locally politically active, you
Speaking of, you mentioned that you follow the news on social media.
I voted and, you know, stuff like that.
guess, what channels or news stations do you rely on the most to get your news?
I was never, like -- you know, a lot of those people that were at
I never even went to their website or
But I generally usually watch, let's see, like, ABC.
I listen to NPR while I'm driving
And then I'll watch FOX too and OAN, which is One America News Network;
CNN occasionally just because I like to, like, get a bounce off, back and forth.
But generally what I do is I bounce around.
I have an app that puts all different
news together, and so, that way, I'm less likely to be biased by going to a site.
headlines that I am interested in reading, and then I go into that.
day reading about science and stuff and never even read into politics.
deal reading a day, about 3 or 4 hours.
And then, similarly, I understand the channels or the news sources, but what
social media applications did you, if you used any, to --
Well, at that time, I had a Twitter and a Facebook and a TikTok.
an lnstagram for my store, but I didn't use it, because I had the kids who, like, ran the
Like, my managers and stuff, they managed that, so I didn't really go on there for
And I would just see posts on there, but --
-- I usually am the type that I cross-reference it, though.
a -- I'm more analytical, I guess you would say.
So, if I see who wrote the article, then I'll kind of -- I even like to look up who
is writing the article and have they had any political biases in the past on this topic or on
other topics that I'm, you know, into.
skewed in the wrong direction or not.
That way, I can kind of devise whether it's being
I would say I spend a lot more time going into it than the average person,
I forgot to ask earlier, did you rely on any, like, traditional print media, like The
New York Times or Wall Street Journal or anything like that?
Journal to read their things, and so -- but I work with the internet, so, you know, it's just a
different letter at the end of that URL, and it changes so you don't have to pay to read
Yeah, but they have online things, so I don't get a subscription for them
And generally you have to -- you have to pay for The Wall Street
Common knowledge on the internet, like, for people who do what I do.
I'm going to go through quite a few social media applications, and let me know if
you used them in the time period, I would say, during former President Trump's
Presidency or even in the lead-up to the election of 2020.
No, I don't -- I don't really -- you mean, like, used their application?
Yeah, did you use their application?
I've never been on their thing, no.
I know you already said Facebook, correct?
Yeah, I have -- I have a Reddit.
And when I say were you using this, I guess in that 2020 timeframe, were
I mean, I've seen 4chan, like, articles and stuff, but not --
But I use Reddit for all kinds of stuff, mostly video game knowledge,
And Reddit's very, very skewed in one direction on some things, but you can
go to specific posts, but -- yeah.
I had Telegram, but it was just, like, a texting app.
social media stuff that's involved with it.
was, like, texting, just, like, a multimedia thing.
As far as I know, I just had a Telegram, and it
So you weren't, like, in any channels or anything like that on
I don't know enough about that.
told me that it was more secure communication.
Signal, which is one of the other ones.
It's literally, one of my friends just
And so I downloaded it, along with
Yeah, I didn't use TikTok until really after January 6th.
But I don't go there for information.
You used both of those, correct?
It's -- I don't go there for political
I really don't even use it anymore, honestly.
YouTube documentaries and different stuff on there occasionally.
Like, nature documentaries and stuff like that.
different -- yeah, I mean, I'm very into all kinds of subjects, so history -- I like to watch
Did you go to the TheDonald.win?
Discord -- like, our Discord channels -- I used to run a server
on a video game called Rust, and so I have a bunch of friends who play on there.
that's the easiest way to communicate across the world, because I have friends who are,
like, all over the world that are in our, what they call a clan.
That's what I use Discord for.
And if you had to pick one or a couple of these sites that I just went through,
So what about a separate site, TheDonald.win?
I've never -- I didn't know it existed.
which source did you rely on the most for your news?
I wouldn't say I relied on any of those for news.
rely on news, is from social media.
I'm saying I saw news that was on social media, but that wasn't where I got my news
I never relied on any social media for news.
Like I said, I use an app that breaks down all the news.
particular app sends me different -- from every different, you know, website, all, like,
Scientific America and also CNN and Wall Street Journal and FOX and, like --
Is this Apple News you're talking about?
And it basically compiles all these different -- it gives me local news, tech,
travel, science, all that, and so it just puts it all into one thing.
Did you follow former President Trump on social media?
What site did you follow him on?
So, right after the general election in 2020, did you believe that the election
was stolen from former President Trump?
I guess, what made you believe that the election had been stolen?
Well, at the time, it was videos mostly, people stuffing ballot boxes in
out within days of the election.
And these are videos that come
So, by January 6th, we had had a variety of videos from all over.
geocaching, phone-caching data that was used to analyze -- it's just like the movie that's
coming out in May, the "2,000 Mules."
Dinesh D'Souza -- see, that's one of the things, is, like, it always
seems like people in politics are about a month or a year behind everyone in the real
And I know that sounds kind of crazy, but it really does, like -- stuff
that was released previously isn't getting re-released until later.
I mean, Michael Sussmann and Hillary Clinton and them doing the investigations
into Durham right now -- with Durham right now.
coming out now, as we're sitting here.
And, you know, those things are still
There's more and more things that keep coming
And so it only reinvigorates everyone out there who still believes it.
Like, I don't think he's still the President.
Do you still believe the election was stolen?
I don't really know what to believe.
Well, it sounds like you started to believe that the election was stolen very
close to the election, if not, like, that night or days after.
Well, it's very strange whenever they deliver ballots in a truck in the middle
of the night, at 3 o'clock in the morning, when that State's regulatory laws say at 8 o'clock
the ballots are supposed to stop.
You know, like, all those little election irregularities -- and there's been tons of
people -- like, I follow all of that because I was involved, right?
about all the time, all the different cases, right?
have been caught with election fraud in multiple States still, and they're still getting
So all these things I read
And there are plenty of people who
But everyone acts like each one of those little incidents isn't enough to add up,
And that's why I thought that there should've been audits.
And that's why -- another reason, that day, on January 6th, I didn't go there to
break in or stop the certification of anything.
I didn't go in at all --
When you're saying you didn't go in at all,
But are you talking about, like, going inside the Capitol or --
The prosecutor said I didn't go inside.
No, you didn't go inside the Capitol.
I didn't go inside the Capitol Building, so -- yeah.
We'll get into that later, about where you were on the Capitol Grounds and
Did you participate in any activities after the general election related to alleged
Like, any rallies or anything like that.
Did you go to any events or help complete any affidavits for any lawsuits
related to election irregularities -- alleged election irregularities?
Just to confirm, you did not go to rallies protesting the 2020 election in
Were you recruited for any of these type of efforts related to
Or the December 12th rally in D.C. either, you didn't go to that one?
The one and only rally I've ever been to is the January 6th.
So, I guess, tell us about the factors that influenced you to come to D.C. for
And I'd like to note, before you answer that, that my colleague
also an investigative counsel, has joined this deposition.
But getting back to my question, tell us about any factors that influenced your
The reason why I came was, I had recently gotten with a new girlfriend, and
she has a dad who was a chaplain in the Army, and him and five other guys were going to
go to the Stop the Steal rally on January 6th.
advance, and my girlfriend said it would probably be a good idea to go.
They told me about it a few days in
And I've thought about the reason why she said that, and the reason was because
it was more of, like, a bonding opportunity for me and her dad to get to know each other
after, you know, we had just kind of gotten together.
And they're a very close family.
So I figured 8 hours in the car to D.C. -- and I hadn't been to D.C. as an adult.
been there as a child, like, 3 or 4 years old.
Monument and the Lincoln Memorial and see the White House and the Capitol Building.
And so that's why I went.
So I kind of wanted to go to the Washington
I didn't really go to go to voice anything.
my intention to go at all.
You said her father was in the Army as well?
I forgot to ask earlier, what led to your other-than-honorable
It's extenuating circumstances, but I'd rather not discuss it.
What's on your paperwork that says why you got an other than honorable.
Was it an Article 15, a court-martial?
And what is the substantiation for it?
Was it due to letters of
What led to that discharge characterization?
Did anything that the former President say to you influence you to make you want
Do you recall the President's December 19th tweet talking about the rally?
I guess you said a couple days before your girlfriend at the time asked you to
Can you give us, like, a possible date or approximate date of when you decided
He had texted me and said he was going.
And, you know, I talked to her.
She said, I mean, yeah, it'd probably be cool to go.
you know, what do you think?
I told her all the reasons I hadn't been.
So it wasn't like she convinced me or nothing.
She just said, you know, it probably wouldn't be a bad idea.
And then I went, and we just rode there in a van full of Christian guys who all, like,
They're all older than I was, in their 40s or 50s.
only went up to the -- all of them, except for him, went only to the Ellipse park area.
So did you look at any social media posts or websites about the rallies going on on
I knew that there was going to be a Stop the Steal rally, but I
hadn't really gotten into it, because I wasn't ever, like, into -- the only thing I did was, he
sent me a link for the event for Ellipse park, which was a list of things that you couldn't
bring into the Ellipse park to go through Secret Service.
So we did not bring anything that could be -- we didn't bring any flags or signs.
Bags couldn't be over a certain size.
I had a Camel Bak, but it said on there that it was up
So we were trying to get there to get into Ellipse park, to be up close enough.
And we got there early, but we were still -- there was, like, a mile long all the way -- it
was, like, all the way around the -- it was, like, all the way around the -- sorry.
It was all the way around the Washington Monument.
to go and try and get in the line to get in, and we just ended up walking around.
Did you follow Ali Alexander during this time
I guess, as you were coming to D.C. for January 6th, I know your father -- or your

I don't know who that is.
girlfriend's father sent you the Ellipse portion handout.
you were particularly excited to see for January 6th?
Was former President Trump one of the reasons why you wanted to come, I
I didn't know who was going to be there other than Trump.
What are some of the others, other reasons?
To see the Washington Monument and the Lincoln Memorial and the Capitol
Building and the White House and the historic place of our country, because I'd never
been there except when I was 3.
Did you do those touristy things and stuff when you came down?
I did that all that morning while they were -- because we were
anticipating having to stand in line, like I said.
And since the line was so long, we ended
up just walking around and taking pictures at a couple of the places -- you know, National
Were there any other elected officials, other than former President Trump,
that, I guess, you might've been excited to see or might've influenced your decision to
want to be in D.C. that day?
No, because I didn't know who was going to be speaking.
Well, I guess, just sum this up for us, just to put a pin in it,

All I heard was it was supposed to be, like, a million-person rally, and it was
going to be this really giant rally.
And I wanted to bond with my girlfriend's dad, see
D.C., see a little bit of Trump there, and be around that many people I'd never been

How are you doing, Mr. Cantwell?
do you have any followup there?
And I'm sorry I was a

I mean, I didn't know exactly all of everything he would be bringing up that
just -- he says the same stuff at all the rallies anyways.
time with her dad, you know.
I wasn't necessarily excited to hear him, you know, say anything particular,
I watch him usually on VouTube.
who Ali Alexander was at the time.
be, like, a Stop the Steal event?
I just went mostly so I could spend

And that was the only way I knew about it.
Like, there's rallies all the time, and I don't, like -- I don't put any mental effort into
Like, where they're at or who's going to be there.
Because I generally don't care, so -- because I don't go to rallies.
and the last one I will go to.
they were going to be looking at evidence of election fraud in a variety of States in the
the evidence was supposed to be heard until everyone broke in.

Like, I didn't go there for any

Well, yeah, I'm sure he would've.
Yeah, I mean, that seems kind of

I mean, you're saying it's obvious.
So it sounds like you did follow the news
It's called Stop the Steal rally.
You don't have to be a

First rally that President Trump spoke at.
It was a Women for America
Stop the Steal was a separate rally.
So I guess that's why I'm asking, what were you following in the lead-up to January
Well, I will correct you though.
Well, that's what I'm saying, is that all I ever heard of was a Stop the Steal
That's all that was on -- all that I was told.
So when did you arrive in Washington, D.C.?
And you said you and your girlfriend's father and his friends all carpooled
Did you stay the night at all in D.C., or did you all just come up for January
We just came up for January 6th.

He rented a van -- one of the guys there rented a van and drove us.
As a matter of fact, I was expecting there to be none.
want there to be none -- we were hoping that there wouldn't be any.
Because there had been so many -- every time that there was protests or rallies,
there was always antifa or somebody else there as well.
Or vice versa, when antifa or
something, then the Proud Boys or somebody would show up.
We were hoping that, since it was in D.C., that that wouldn't happen.
I guess, how familiar before January 6th or

It's just a -- I knew that it was a -- like, originally supposed to be, like, some
Christian group of conservatives, and then I guess they became radicalized or something.
But that's just from reading from the news, and that's a var- -- like, from
It's just like seeing antifa or Black Lives Matter or any of these other groups that

Who the Proud Boys were before January 6th.

Yeah, I was aware of who they were.

Generally CNN articles was talking about the Proud Boys.

The same way you know who al-Qaida or ISIS is.
I guess, overall, how were you aware of who these organizations
Like, you hear about them on the news.
down places and fighting with each other on the streets.

So, I guess, where did you see news articles about the Proud Boys fighting?
What was it in relation to?

You don't recall the Proud Boys being reported on
from the December rally in D.C.?
You don't remember the Proud Boys being reported on from the November

like, when they were in -- what is it -- Kenosha, Michigan, and all that over there.
It's mostly you see them in California and,

And I remember there was violence whenever he walked across to that
church and they had to spread open the crowd so he could do a photo-op.
I'll call it like I see it.
But those were all people from the left, though.
That was -- you know what I mean?
So I didn't see people from the
I thought it was just going to be a big

Generally, the only time that anything bad happens is when he tells some idiot to

I wouldn't have expected that, because so many people and it being -- I just wasn't
But not, like, full-on -- do you know what I mean?
So let's get into January 6th, then.
So you arrive at 3:00 a.m., approximately 3:00 a.m.
What do you do in the

Pennsylvania Avenue, though, not far past Chinatown and -- anyways.

talking in the parking deck downstairs.
with, like, a bajillion Trump stickers and stuff, like, down in the basement with other cars,

made a right on, I think it's Continental.

program on the Ellipse at all, for any of the speeches?

So, basically, at 6 o'clock, like, we got there, and some of us stayed in -- like,
we kind of set up outside of the Ellipse park.
fencing that surrounds Ellipse park, and then there was, like, a bunch of vendors and

picked, like, a spot there where we would all line up and meet back at.

And the Washington Monument was back behind it,

Mostly they just tried to find bathrooms and stuff.
And then me and Jody walked

And we met a bunch of people.
We were walking around, and we talked to -- I

and, you know, they were like, "We don't want communism in America."
And they had big, you know, "Down with the CCP" things up,
You know, there was just a bunch of really -- mostly everybody was happy,
front of Ellipse, people were singing and dancing and talking with each other.
And, like, that's all I did.
Like, the whole time we were at the rally there in
We just went there, and I walked to the Washington
Monument, took pictures there, down to the Lincoln Memorial and there.
picture somewhere with my middle finger up, I'm sure, in front of the IRS building as a
But that was pretty much -- my entire morning was just kind of walking around in
